name: Los Cabos
meta_title: Los Cabos Travel Guide 2025 - Cabo San Lucas & San José del Cabo | Top Mexico Travel
meta_description: Discover Los Cabos, where the Pacific meets the Sea of Cortez. Explore world-class resorts, championship golf, whale watching, sport fishing, and the iconic El Arco in this complete Cabo travel guide.
og_image_alt: El Arco rock formation at Land's End in Cabo San Lucas
hero_image_alt: Dramatic El Arco rock formation at sunset in Los Cabos
tagline: Where desert meets sea — Mexico's most spectacular luxury escape at land's end
featured_snippet_intro: Los Cabos sits at the dramatic southern tip of the Baja California Peninsula, where the Pacific Ocean meets the Sea of Cortez. This sun-drenched destination encompasses lively Cabo San Lucas and artsy San José del Cabo, connected by world-class resorts, championship golf courses, and stunning desert-meets-ocean landscapes.
introduction:
Los Cabos has transformed from a remote fishing outpost into one of Mexico's most prestigious resort destinations, attracting celebrities, golfers, and sun-seekers with its unique geography and year-round sunshine (350+ sunny days annually). The iconic El Arco—a natural rock arch at Land's End—has become one of Mexico's most photographed landmarks.

The region offers two distinct experiences: Cabo San Lucas is the lively hub, famous for its marina, sport fishing fleet, beach clubs, and legendary nightlife. Twenty miles northeast, San José del Cabo offers a more refined experience with its historic downtown, art galleries, farm-to-table restaurants, and beautiful estuary. The Tourist Corridor connecting them hosts mega-resorts, world-ranked golf courses, and pristine swimming beaches.

Whether you're here for the party scene, a romantic getaway, world-class fishing, championship golf, or simply to bask in the desert sun, Los Cabos delivers a Mexican vacation unlike any other.

attractions.name: El Arco de Cabo San Lucas
attractions.description: The iconic natural rock arch at Land's End where the Pacific meets the Sea of Cortez. This dramatic granite formation is Cabo's most famous symbol, best viewed by boat at sunrise or sunset.
attractions.tip: Book a glass-bottom boat to see sea lions and tropical fish on the way.

attractions.name: Medano Beach
attractions.description: Cabo's main swimmable beach and social hub with beach clubs, restaurants, water sports, jet skis, parasailing, and famous party atmosphere.
attractions.tip: Mango Deck and The Office are the liveliest beach clubs. Arrive early for prime spots.

attractions.name: Lover's Beach & Divorce Beach
attractions.description: Secluded beaches at Land's End accessible only by water taxi. Lover's Beach (Sea of Cortez side) is swimmable; Divorce Beach (Pacific side) has dangerous currents—admire only.
attractions.tip: Bring everything you need—there are no facilities. Water taxis leave from Medano Beach.

attractions.name: San José del Cabo Art District
attractions.description: Historic downtown with galleries, boutiques, and restaurants. The famous Thursday night Art Walk (November-June) features gallery openings and live music.
attractions.tip: Art Walk runs 5-9pm on Thursdays from November through June. Dress up a bit for the occasion.

attractions.name: Whale Watching
attractions.description: Gray and humpback whales migrate through Cabo waters December-April. Watch them breach, spout, and nurse calves in one of the world's best whale watching destinations.
attractions.tip: Peak viewing is January-March. Book with operators that maintain safe distances from whales.

attractions.name: Sport Fishing
attractions.description: The 'Marlin Capital of the World' offers year-round fishing for marlin, tuna, dorado, wahoo, and more. Over 30,000 marlin are caught annually in these waters.
attractions.tip: October-November is peak marlin season. Book boats through the marina for best selection.

attractions.name: Flora Farms
attractions.description: Magical 25-acre organic farm in the foothills with farm-to-table restaurant, cooking classes, spa, and beautiful grounds. A must-visit Cabo experience.
attractions.tip: Reserve for dinner to experience the magical evening atmosphere with twinkling lights.

attractions.name: Santa María Beach
attractions.description: Protected horseshoe bay with calm, crystal-clear water perfect for swimming and snorkeling. One of Cabo's best family-friendly beaches.
attractions.tip: Arrive before 10am for parking and calmer waters. Bring snorkel gear to explore the marine life.

attractions.name: Chileno Beach
attractions.description: Blue Flag certified beach with calm waters, good snorkeling, and public facilities. One of the safest swimming beaches in Los Cabos.
attractions.tip: Public facilities include bathrooms, showers, and lifeguards. Rent snorkel gear on-site.

attractions.name: Cabo Pulmo National Park
attractions.description: UNESCO World Heritage marine park with North America's oldest coral reef. World-class diving and snorkeling with abundant marine life including whale sharks.
attractions.tip: Book a guided tour—the park is 2 hours from Cabo. October-November is whale shark season.

neighborhoods.name: Cabo San Lucas Marina
neighborhoods.description: The lively heart of Cabo San Lucas, with the marina, fishing fleet, restaurants, bars, and shops. This is where the party happens and boats depart for El Arco and Medano Beach.
neighborhoods.best_for: Nightlife seekers, first-time visitors, fishing enthusiasts

neighborhoods.name: Medano Beach Area
neighborhoods.description: The main beach zone in Cabo San Lucas with beach clubs, hotels, and the liveliest atmosphere. The only significant swimmable beach in Cabo town proper.
neighborhoods.best_for: Beach lovers, party seekers, spring breakers

neighborhoods.name: San José del Cabo Historic Center
neighborhoods.description: The charming colonial heart of San José with art galleries, boutiques, excellent restaurants, and the beautiful main plaza. Much quieter and more refined than Cabo San Lucas.
neighborhoods.best_for: Art lovers, couples, those seeking culture

neighborhoods.name: Tourist Corridor (Corredor Turístico)
neighborhoods.description: The 20-mile stretch between Cabo San Lucas and San José del Cabo, lined with luxury resorts, championship golf courses, and the best swimming beaches.

neighborhoods.name: Pedregal
neighborhoods.description: Ultra-exclusive residential area on the Pacific side of Cabo San Lucas, accessible through a tunnel. Home to Waldorf Astoria and the most expensive real estate.

featured_hotels.name: Waldorf Astoria Los Cabos Pedregal
featured_hotels.description: Cliffside masterpiece accessed through a mountain tunnel. Every room has a private plunge pool, fireplace, and unobstructed Pacific views. The pinnacle of Cabo luxury.

featured_hotels.name: One&Only Palmilla
featured_hotels.description: Legendary resort on one of Cabo's few swimmable beaches. Impeccable service, Jean-Georges restaurant, 27-hole golf course, and celebrity favorite status.

featured_hotels.name: The Cape, a Thompson Hotel
featured_hotels.description: Contemporary design hotel perched on Monuments Beach with rooftop bar, Manta restaurant by Enrique Olvera, and stunning sunset views.

featured_hotels.name: ME Cabo
featured_hotels.description: Stylish beachfront hotel on Medano Beach with rooftop pool, party atmosphere, and front-row seats to the Cabo scene.

featured_hotels.name: The Bungalows Hotel
featured_hotels.description: Charming breakfast-included boutique hotel in San José del Cabo's art district. Excellent value with personalized service and beautiful grounds.

featured_hotels.name: Hotel Mar de Cortez
featured_hotels.description: Simple, clean hotel in downtown Cabo San Lucas. Walking distance to marina and nightlife. Best budget option in expensive Cabo.

featured_restaurants.name: Flora Farms
featured_restaurants.description: Magical 25-acre organic farm with outdoor restaurant under twinkling lights. Fresh ingredients from the surrounding fields. The ultimate Cabo dining experience.

featured_restaurants.name: El Farallon
featured_restaurants.description: Dramatic cliffside restaurant at Waldorf Astoria carved into the rocks above the Pacific. Choose your fish from the champagne bar display case.

featured_restaurants.name: Manta (The Cape)
featured_restaurants.description: Chef Enrique Olvera's (Pujol, Cosme) beachfront restaurant featuring Baja-inspired cuisine with stunning ocean views.

featured_restaurants.name: The Office on the Beach
featured_restaurants.description: Iconic feet-in-the-sand restaurant on Medano Beach. Order shrimp tacos, drink margaritas, and people-watch all day.

featured_restaurants.name: Tacos Guss
featured_restaurants.description: Local favorite in San José del Cabo for authentic fish and shrimp tacos. Simple, cheap, delicious.

featured_restaurants.name: Sunset Monalisa
featured_restaurants.description: Romantic cliffside restaurant in Pedregal with panoramic sunset views over the Pacific. Perfect for special occasions.

featured_restaurants.name: Don Sanchez
featured_restaurants.description: San José's premier contemporary Mexican restaurant in a beautiful colonial courtyard setting.

featured_restaurants.name: La Lupita Taco & Mezcal
featured_restaurants.description: Hip taco and mezcal bar in San José with creative tacos, extensive mezcal selection, and lively atmosphere.

day_trips.name: Todos Santos
day_trips.description: Charming artistic pueblo mágico with galleries, cafes, Hotel California (yes, that one), and excellent surf beaches. A world away from Cabo's glitz.
day_trips.tips: Explore the galleries, have lunch at Café Santa Fe, and hit Cerritos Beach for sunset.

day_trips.name: Cabo Pulmo National Park
day_trips.description: UNESCO World Heritage marine park with North America's oldest coral reef. World-class diving and snorkeling with massive schools of fish.
day_trips.tips: Book a guided tour with snorkel/dive included. October-November brings whale sharks.

day_trips.name: La Paz
day_trips.description: Baja's capital city with beautiful malecón, excellent seafood, and access to Espíritu Santo Island for sea lion snorkeling.
day_trips.tips: Make it an overnight trip. Boat tours to Espíritu Santo are unforgettable.

day_trips.name: Sierra de la Laguna
day_trips.description: Mountain biosphere reserve with hiking, canyon rappelling, hot springs, and a break from beach heat. Home to endemic species.
day_trips.tips: Book a guided adventure tour with transportation. Great for hiking enthusiasts.

faqs.question: What is the difference between Cabo San Lucas and San José del Cabo?
faqs.answer: Cabo San Lucas is the party town with marina nightlife, beach clubs, and touristy atmosphere. San José del Cabo is quieter and more refined, with a historic downtown, art galleries, and upscale restaurants. The Tourist Corridor between them has most luxury resorts and golf courses. Choose based on whether you want energy or tranquility.

faqs.question: Can you swim at the beaches in Los Cabos?
faqs.answer: Many Pacific-facing beaches have dangerous waves and undertow. Safe swimming beaches include: Medano Beach in Cabo San Lucas, Chileno Beach, Santa María Beach, and the beach at Palmilla resort. Always check conditions and flags. Never swim at Divorce Beach or unmarked Pacific beaches.

faqs.question: When is the best time to visit Los Cabos?
faqs.answer: November to June offers ideal weather with minimal rain and 350+ sunny days annually. December-April is peak season (and whale watching season). Summer (July-October) brings humidity, potential hurricanes, occasional rain, but also lower prices and excellent fishing.

faqs.question: Is Los Cabos safe for tourists?
faqs.answer: Los Cabos tourist areas are generally very safe. The economy depends heavily on tourism, and security is prioritized. Use normal precautions, avoid isolated areas at night, and book tours through reputable operators. Downtown Cabo San Lucas can get rowdy late at night—stay aware.

faqs.question: How do I get from the airport to my hotel?
faqs.answer: San José del Cabo International Airport (SJD) is about 20 minutes from San José and 45 minutes from Cabo San Lucas. Options: private transfer ($60-100 USD), shared shuttle ($20-30 per person), taxi, or rental car. Most luxury resorts offer complimentary or fee-based airport transfers.

faqs.question: Is Los Cabos expensive?
faqs.answer: Yes, Los Cabos is one of Mexico's most expensive destinations due to its luxury positioning and remote Baja location. Resort rates often exceed $500/night at top properties. Budget travelers can find mid-range options in downtown areas, but beach resorts and fine dining are pricey. Eating at local spots saves money.

faqs.question: What is the best area to stay in Los Cabos?
faqs.answer: For parties and beaches: Medano Beach in Cabo San Lucas. For art and refinement: San José del Cabo centro. For luxury resorts and golf: Tourist Corridor (Palmilla, Chileno Bay area). For ultra-luxury privacy: Pedregal in Cabo San Lucas. Most first-timers choose the Tourist Corridor for a balance.

faqs.question: When is whale watching season in Los Cabos?
faqs.answer: Gray and humpback whales visit Los Cabos waters from December through April, with peak viewing January-March. Whale watching tours depart daily during season, lasting 2-3 hours. Sightings are nearly guaranteed during peak months. Book with operators that maintain safe distances.

faqs.question: Is the golf in Los Cabos really that good?
faqs.answer: Yes, Los Cabos is a world-class golf destination with courses designed by Jack Nicklaus, Tiger Woods, Greg Norman, and other legends. The desert-ocean landscape creates spectacular settings. Top courses include Palmilla, Cabo del Sol, and Diamante. Green fees range from $200-400+ USD.

faqs.question: How many days do you need in Los Cabos?
faqs.answer: 4-5 days is ideal to enjoy beaches, dining, a day trip (Todos Santos or whale watching), and perhaps golf or fishing. With 3 days you can see highlights but will feel rushed. A week allows for full relaxation and multiple activities without hurrying.

getting_there: San José del Cabo International Airport (SJD) has direct flights from most major US cities, Canada, and Mexico City. The airport is 20 minutes from San José del Cabo and 45 minutes from Cabo San Lucas. Private transfers, shared shuttles, taxis, and rental cars are available. Most resorts offer airport transportation.
getting_around: The Tourist Corridor requires transportation—taxis, Uber, rental cars, or resort shuttles. Downtown Cabo San Lucas and San José del Cabo's centro are walkable. Taxis are expensive ($20-40 between towns). Uber works well and is cheaper. Renting a car is recommended for exploring beaches and day trips.
safety_info: Los Cabos tourist areas are safe, but use common sense. Don't walk alone on dark beaches at night. Be cautious with alcohol at beach clubs and bars. Only use official taxis or Uber. Downtown Cabo San Lucas can be rowdy late at night—stay in groups. The Tourist Corridor and San José are very safe.
